_chemical.ChemicalName: Hydrogen fluoride/Hydrofluoric acid (conc 50% or greater) [Hydrofluoric acid]

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



November 25, 2016



Introduction



Galaxy Chemicals, LLC 

At Galaxy Chemicals, our top goal is the safety of our employes, the neighbours, the public and environment. To fulfill this goal and commitment, Galaxy Chemicals has establish and practice  system and procedures to porvidie safe operation of the processess at the facility.  Galaxy Chemicals has implemented the risk  management program(RMP) as a part of our safety program.  This program also help us manage the risk at our  facililty and complies wth the requiremens of the Environmental Protection Agency's EPA requlation 40CFR Part 68,  Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs, ( the RMP rule).  This plan is intended to satisfy the Risk Management Plan requirement of the RMP ruls68.150 through 68.185.  This Risk Management Program also provide  public information about this program.



Off Site Consequence Analaysis

The RMP rule requires Galaxy Chemicals to perform an offsite consequence analysis forone worst-case and alternate release scenario for the anhydrous hydrogen fluoride, which is toxic substance. Both worst case and alternate scenario are included in the RMP filing.  

The worst case scenario is the falilure of  6365 gallons storage tank, which releases 50,000 lbs of HF to a toxic  end point of 7.5 miles with a population of 61,677 people.  



The alternate  case scenario uses a copper tube with a leak and developes a 1/8 inch hole.  The HF release is 15 lbs, to a toxic end point of 0.1 mile with a population of 80  people.  No enveironmental receptors are in distance. 



Regulated Substances and Galaxy Chemicals

Galaxy Chemicals uses hydrogen fluoride, HF in many of its manufacturing process in 50% of higher concentration.  These process involve neutralization procedures with hydrogen fluoride and the final products contain trace amounts of hydrogen fluoride.  Hydrogen fluoride is stored in storage tanks for use in manufacturing.



Galaxy Chem

icals stores 33880 lbs(4131 gallons) of anhydrous hydrogen fluoride in 6365 gallon tank located at 6472 Tower Lane, Claremore, OK site.  The weight of this acid exceeds the RMP rule threshold quantity for hydrogen fluoride, HF acid in a process (1000 lbs) and therefore HF acid storage process is covered the requirements of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's process safety managementr egulation and potential offsite consequences resulting from an accidental release of HF acid. This process falls under the RMP Program 3 prevention program.



Emergency Response and Accidental Release Prevention Policies



At Galaxy Chemicals the safety of our employees, neighbours and the public and environment is the top priority and commitment which ensure the preservation of the accidental releases of the hazardous materials. Galaxy Chemicals implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseable releases of hazardous chemicals.  In the  case of an accidental release , Galaxy Chemicals controls and contains the release in a manner that will be safe for workers and will prevent the injury to the public and environment





Accdental Release Prog;ram and Chemical-Speicific Prevention Steps



Under the RMP rule ,  a program 3,  prevention program is required for the storage of anhydrous hydrogen fluoride.,  The following paragraph describe the elements of the prevention program at Galaxy Chemicals. 



Process Hazardous Analysis and Safety Informatin



Galaxy Chemicals provide Material Safety 

Data Sheets to its employees for the physical data and safety information about hydrogen fluoride.  The written procedures are also provides and discussed before the start up of manufacturing.  Galaxy Chemicals performs the hazard review of the hydrogen fluoride storage process to control process hazards.  

Operating Procedures

Galaxy Chemicals have developed the operating procedures to perform the work in a safe manner.  These procedures are also use to train. 



Incident

Investigation

Galaxy Chemicals investigate all incidents that could reasonable resulted in  a serious injury to workers, the public and the environment.  The investigation team starts its investigation with in 24 hours of the accident. The results are documented and recommendations implemented to enhance safety.

Training

Regular safety training are provided for the workers and material safety data sheets explained .

Maintenance

Galaxy Chemicals maintains the process equipment to improve the safety of the worker and the public and the environment.  Regular inspection are done to identiy the equipment damage or deterioration.

Management of Change and Compliance Audits

Galaxy Chemicals performs and compliance audits of the covered processes to verify that the processes are operating in compliance with the requirements of the RMP rule.

Accident History

Galaxy Chemicals maintains a good record and no releases of regulated substances have occured from Galaxy Chemicals since our operation from May of 2002 to date.

emergency Response Program

Galaxy Chemicals has a written emergency response program that complies with the RMP rule and with other continggency plan regulations.   This plan has been communicated to local emergency reposnse officials .



If you have any questions concerning RMP, call us at (918)379-0820
